I wanted to eat light so I had some hot and sour soup. It was NOT good. It tasted like what you could get at a crappy Americanized Chinese restaurant in a strip mall. (I was longing for Lao Szechwan's spicy, well known stuff.) In fact, some of the soup was barely up to room temperature. The shrimp in it was disgusting, tasting totally fishy and strange.

It gets 3 stars because my boyfriend liked his chicken fried rice, though it took a very long time on a not-too-crowded Friday night. The decor and service were decent-to-good, so that's something.

Good variety of dim sum for lunch.  Great responsive service and authentic Chinese dim sum.  We enjoyed all the dishes.  In particular, we loved the noodles sauteed with seafood, vegetarian dumplings, congee and turnip cake.  Definitely worth more visits.

The best hot and sour soup.
Massive crab rangoons.
Next level Hong Kong style FRESH Dungeness crab. I'm talking like, meat ON meat.  Shrimp and spicy ground pork on top of the fried crab. Will knock you straight on your ass.

Cocktails are strong and decently priced ($7). Service is good- they have a lot of staff.
Gotta make it a point to come back here next time I'm in Chi-town!!

pics.caption: Hong Kong style Dungeness crab. Shrimp and spicy ground pork on top of fried crab!

review.des: Amazing food and service. I have been craving this for a long time. The noodles are fresh and the duck is excellent!

Food was good, service was good. The place has lots of seating (2 floors) and we didn't have to wait for a table for 9 on a Saturday evening around 6.

Only complaint is that some of the dim sum items weren't on the menu (they're on the other location menus all day).

I've eaten at this location multiple times and each time was about the same. Your standard Dim Sum restaurant, one of the best in Chicago considering there aren't very many places to choose from to begin with. Its nice because they offer traditional Cantonese food with a sort of Hong Kong style (basically, expect a clean interior with a dash of fancy).  The interior is well designed with authentic Chinese touches to a modern vibe.

You're automatically given a side of Hoisin sauce and Sriracha... but! Remember to ask for some chili oil and/or soy sauce! These will enhance the flavor of most/all of the small dishes.

Some of my fav Dim Sum dishes:

SAVORY
- Rice Crepe with Deep Fried Chinese Bread (THIS! So good. Nice and crunchy on the inside. Is best with the sauce it comes with and some chili oil.)
- Shrimp Hargao ("Minghin's Shrimp Dumpling" The skin is not too thick or thin, just right.)
- Shrimp Crepe (a personal #1 favorite)
- Siu Mai (a staple, "Pork & Shrimp Dumpling")
- Short Rib with Honey Sauce or Pepper Sauce (both are good imo)

SWEET
- Deep Fried Sesame Ball (Very light and crispy on the outside with some sweet red bean paste inside)
- Egg Tarts! ("Putty Egg Custard Tart")

I've tried the Mini Sweet Custard Rolls not knowing what to expect. They're only okay, a bit dry. Not bad but also not something I would get again.

Overall, no matter what you try here, it'll probably be good! This isn't the best dim sum place I've ever been to, nor is it in my top 5. BUT the right flavors are here and are probably the best in the Chicago area for this. With limited options, this is definitely my go-to place for a quick breakfast/brunch. They also open at 8AM!!! Most other restaurants don't open until around 10/11AM, so good for a meal before a trip out.

The staff are helpful and I've had no problems with them every time I've come. The wait isn't bad either, even on busy weekend mornings. The longest waiting time was about 20 minutes but every other time, we were seated within 5 minutes or less of arriving. Which is SUPER awesome. A lot of other dim sum places I've been to in Southern California typically take 30min-1hr+ just to be seated, so this is really nice.

If you're new to Chinese food, this is a good gateway into the cuisine and culture! And if you're already well-versed, this is a good place to get the basics and those cravings satisfied.

pics.caption: Great way to spend a Sunday morning!

review.des: They stop serving Dimsum at 5 on saturdays! Food is delicious, service is good enough.

For 6 people we ordered a   18 items- totaling ~$150.

Service here is perfect -- so nice, way better than downtown location.

pics.caption: 12.25.17 upstairs seating utilized to accommodate capacity
12.25.17 front entrance is in inner court

review.des:
The venue for this place is really nice. It's open and spacious. They have plenty of seating available so it is good for large groups. The decor is nice too.

We did the dim sum and I was really excited for it. Unfortunately, it wasn't as great as I hoped it would be. The dumplings we got were not good at all. I couldn't even tell you which ones were okay or bad because no one mentioned what they were and if they did, it was fast and quiet.

I really wanted to like this place but I don't think I would come back again.

I've never ordered any other food here besides dim sum, but why would you need to? It's delicious and a good value, especially if you come as a group. We usually come here on Sundays to eat dim sum between 10AM and 1PMish and the wait is usually anywhere from 10-20 minutes which isn't too bad considering it's usually with large (10+) groups.

The last time we came, I notice that they have iPads at the tables now, but we still ordered dim sum off the paper menus where you just mark how much of a dish you want and they bring it out to your table. Service is decent regardless, but if you have a Cantonese speaker with you it's usually a little better/faster.

The items I usually eat when we come here: ha gow, siu mai, chicken feet, spare ribs, shrimp crepe, dough crepe, custard roll, egg tarts. Sometimes the congee with the century eggs and sometimes turnip cakes and sometimes gai lan when I want to pretend I'm being healthy. Lol it's all good to be honest -- I'm not too picky.

For a group of 12 of us we spent about $190 for dim sum including gratuity, so a bit under $16 per person. To be quite honest, we probably could have ordered even less food and still been very full instead of disgustingly full. Fair warning: if you come with a group they can only split payment 6 ways so come with cash or be prepared to Venmo your friends.

The Chinatown location also does late night dim sum from 9PM until 2AM so you don't have to limit your dim sum cravings to just brunch!

Yum!!!! I really enjoyed the dim sum here. I'd say even better than some places in San Gabriel Valley in California. I was delightfully surprised by the juiciness of the dishes. They were quick to get the extra condiments I asked for. The interior was also decorated beautifully. I strongly recommend this restaurant.

One of the nicer and lesser-packed dim sum places in Chinatown. Overall the portion sizes are pretty good and the menu has typically anything that you would want to order. The BBQ buns are amazing especially - I'd make a trip here just to eat those alone. The portion size of the fried rice is also ridiculous.

Weird that they don't have chili oil and soy sauce on the tables though! You can ask for it like we did but they give you Sriracha originally instead and it's just an odd combo lol
